deliberation: Examined temporal markers, military movement, and siege language. Terms like "came" (בָּא), "whole army" (כׇּל־חֵילוֹ), and "laid siege" (וַיָּצֻרוּ) function as standard military-historical description. No metaphors, similes, idioms, or personifications are used; the verse is straightforward narrative.

Considered whether "the city was breached" (הׇבְקְעָה הָעִיר) might be figurative. In context it clearly refers to the literal breach of Jerusalem’s defensive walls, with no signal of metaphorical extension (e.g., moral or spiritual). No figurative language is detected.

This verse lists Babylonian officials and a specific location ("the middle gate"). No expressions of comparison, personification, or metonymic place-for-people usage beyond straightforward political and military reference. The language is purely referential and literal.

Checked whether "the king’s garden," "the gate between the walls," or "the Arabah" function metaphorically. All function as concrete topographical markers in a historical escape narrative. No idioms or figurative uses appear; the verbs "fled" and "went out" are literal.

Reviewed pursuit/overtaking language and the legal term "he spoke judgments with him" (וַיְדַבֵּר אִתּוֹ מִשְׁפָּטִים). These all describe literal military and judicial actions, not metaphorical judgment scenes. No metaphor, simile, or idiomatic expressions beyond normal legal usage.

The verbs "slaughtered" (וַיִּשְׁחַט) and references to sons and nobles are horrific but literal descriptions of execution. There is no figurative extension (e.g., "slaughter" used metaphorically for defeat); it is concrete, physical killing.

Examined whether "blinded" and "bronze fetters" might be symbolic. In context these are standard punitive measures and instruments of captivity, not metaphorical depictions of spiritual blindness or bondage. The verse is descriptively literal.

Considered whether burning the houses and tearing down the walls could be symbolic of judgment or social collapse. In this narrative setting they describe actual destruction of palace, homes, and fortifications. No figurative formulas (e.g., "fire" for passion) are present; it is concrete warfare imagery.

"The remnant of the people" (יֶתֶר הָעָם) and "those who fell to him" (הַנֹּפְלִים) are technical population and political terms (remaining inhabitants, defectors). They are not functioning as metaphors for a spiritual remnant here but as census-like categories. Exile language is literal deportation.

Reviewed "the poorest of the people" and the gift of "vineyards and cisterns" for figurative poverty/wealth contrasts. Here they are socio-economic descriptors and actual agricultural holdings redistributed by the conqueror. No figurative or idiomatic construction stands out.

Checked royal command formula and especially the phrase "in the hand of Nebuzaradan" (בְּיַד נְבוּזַרְאֲדָן). This is a standard Hebrew idiom/metonymy where "hand" stands for agency or control, not a literal physical hand passing something. One figurative instance is present.

instances.explanation: "Hand" is a metonymy and idiom for someone’s power or agency; here it means the command is entrusted to Nebuzaradan to carry out, not literally placed in his physical hand.

deliberation: This verse lists officials and the fact that they "sent" (וַיִּשְׁלַח) for Jeremiah. "Send" here is literal, not figurative for commissioning or spiritual sending. No metaphorical titles or personifications occur beyond standard offices.

Checked whether "court of the guard" or "he dwelt among the people" might be idiomatic or symbolic. Here they describe literal confinement conditions and Jeremiah’s physical residence with the populace. No figurative expressions detected.

Looked at the prophetic formula "the word of YHWH came to Jeremiah" (הָיָה דְבַר־יְהוָה אֶל־יִרְמְיָהוּ). This treats the "word" as if it is a thing that can "be" to someone, and uses "word" metonymically for divine revelation. It is a conventional figurative-prophetic formula.

deliberation: Identified two figurative elements: (1) "I am bringing my words upon this city for evil and not for good" objectifies and metonymically uses "words" for decrees/events; (2) "they will be before your face on that day" uses spatial imagery for immediate personal experience. Both are conventional prophetic figures.
